sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1:
Calculate the change in entropy and enthalpy for the reaction of iron (III) oxide with carbon monoxide to form iron and carbon dioxide, given the following information:
Fe2O3(s) + 3CO(g) → 2Fe(s) + 3CO2(g)
ΔH°f (Fe2O3) = -824.2 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (CO) = -110.5 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (Fe) = 0 kJ/mol
ΔH°f (CO2) = -393.5 kJ/mol
ΔS° (Fe2O3) = 87.4 J/K mol
ΔS° (CO) = 197.9 J/K mol
ΔS° (Fe) = 27.3 J/K mol
ΔS° (CO2) = 213.6 J/K mol
message_2:
To calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH = Σ ΔH°f (products) - Σ ΔH°f (reactants)

ΔH = [2ΔH°f (Fe) + 3ΔH°f (CO2)] - [ΔH°f (Fe2O3) + 3ΔH°f (CO)]

ΔH = [2(0) + 3(-393.5)] - [(-824.2) + 3(-110.5)]
ΔH = [-1180.5] - [-1155.7]
ΔH = -24.8 kJ/mol

Now, to calculate the change in entropy (ΔS) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔS = Σ ΔS° (products) - Σ ΔS° (reactants)

ΔS = [2ΔS° (Fe) + 3ΔS° (CO2)] - [ΔS° (Fe2O3) + 3ΔS° (CO)]

ΔS = [2(27.3) + 3(213.6)] - [(87.4) + 3(197.9)]
ΔS = [54.6 + 640.8] - [87.4 + 593.7]
ΔS = 695.4 - 681.1
ΔS = 14.3 J/K mol

So, the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction is -24.8 kJ/mol, and the change in entropy (ΔS) is 14.3 J/K mol.
